c4p.content:
DevFest Galway was announced, for the sixth year in a row, the conference will bring together 900 developers, managers and entrepreneurs on **October 13-14** to Lviv. This year our team is doing big advancement in the content, we're building an extra stage to accommodate more visitors and provide three fully independent tracks on Android, Web and Google Cloud topics. Our focus is the content. **We’re looking for speakers like you**, who are ready to rock the stage and deliver the best talk or workshop in the field. "I've been to conferences all over the world and what you've created in Lviv is world class. It's easily first league of conferences." - Piotr Tuszynski, DevFest '16 Keynote Speaker
Submit a proposal
## Why is it cool to speak at the DevFest? DevFest Ukraine is not an ordinary tech conference, besides selecting only the best speakers, we help them to succeed in delivering an exceptional quality talk on the stage. Here are few perks that all our speakers get: - **Expences covered**. Hotel for 3 nights, travel costs and entrance to exclusive speaker parties are covered for all speakers. - **Professional video recording**. We work with experienced video production companies to create session recording of the best quality. Stage, screen, audio, all is recorded separately and combined later. Check the [session videos from the last year](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VOwUnBkqmo4). - **Exposure**. By being a speaker, you are proving your level of expertise to a potential business partners or employers. Your talk will be promoted in our online resources and recording published in YouTube channel with more than 35k views. - **Unique networking**. Being a speaker means you’ll have the unique chance to network with other speakers - the best experts in the industry. - **Coaching**. We're in the same boat, after being selected as a speaker our program committee will help you to deliver the best talk possible. We provide information about the audience, presentation templates, feedback on the slides, all to help you to prepare. "It was a best DevFest I ever attended. So professional, so much enthusiasm from the community. You managed to bring the vibe of Google I/O to Ukraine." - David Vávra, DevFest '16 Speaker ## What are we looking for? We're looking for **experience-based talks**, the information that can not be found in the documentation or easily googled. We're looking for your stories, your struggles, research results and experiences with the frontier tools or technologies. Check the [list of topics](https://docs.google.com/document/d/18eGvBr6wdlXsfiZM4EK6SubfL3G1RWj-ABTBN9pngNg/edit?usp=sharing) we're interested in (it is not full and updated all the time). ### Format You can submit as many talks as you want. This year we accept submissions in two formats: - 40 minutes sessions. - 2(or 3) hours workshops. ### Talks that will not pass initial review - Talks about a specific tool/library/project explaining how it works or how to use it. - Talks whose focus is pitching a company or project. It’s cool that you mention your company during the presentation, but it shouldn’t be the focus of the talk. - Proposals that are not in English. - Recruitment talks to attract talent. We strongly recommend you check out [speaking.io](http://speaking.io/) website from Zach Holman. It includes good tips and guidelines for speakers. ## Timeline **Call for Papers submission deadline is July 1, 2017.** Submission results will be announced by July 16. Any questions? Email organizers at [devfest@gdg.org.ua](mailto:devfest@gdg.org.ua)
Submit a proposal
c4p.title: We're looking for speakers

101.description: Get your badge, coffee, enjoy talking with tech edicts around
101.title: Registration & morning Coffee

102.description: Official start of the conference. Greetings from the organizers, sponsors and partners.
102.title: DevFest Galway 2019 Opening

104.description: Using AlphaGo as a motivation, I will give basics on neural networks and reinforcement learning techniques. If time permits, I will go into details on how AlphaGo and his Zero derivatives work.
104.title: AlphaGo and his family, a striking improvement in AI: the five Ws

105.description: Machine Learning is one of the most trendy things in IT world right now, a bunch of new services pop-up every single moment, large companies have started to implement different features that utilise Machine Learning(ML). But.... how mortal developers and small and medium business can effectively use machine learn to improve their solutions? In this talk, we are going to discuss the basic concepts around ML and using high-level libraries in JavaScript to implement on our project. Described as a friendly Machine Learning library ml5.js will be our entry door to the Machine Learning world. To wrap up the introduction journey, we will see how we can use ml5.js in a real project. As I mentioned before ml5.js is a Javascript library - the talk is focused on a front-end stack but is open for people who want to learn more about the basic concepts behind machine learning. Let's get coding!!!
105.title: Machine learning for mortal developers

106.description: Neurodiversity is a concept where neurological differences are to be recognized and respected as any other human variation. The term is used mostly used for Autism and ADHD; this talk will focus on Autism, a brief introduction and then dive into the benefits of neurodiversity for the workplace and how we can make a difference today. We all know diversity is essential, but neurodiversity is often overlooked since it is invisible.
106.title: Neurodiversity

108.description: Innovation in wearables was historically driven by the clothes and fashion industry as they looked for cheaper, durable, washable textiles. Now we see wearable innovations focused on health and  sustainability. In this talk we will look at where we are with wearables and what the future might bring.
108.title: Fur to Fitbits: the evolution of wearable technology

110.description: During this codelab, Julien will use Firebase and Cloud AI APIs to create a Smart Photo Library that organizes pictures automatically based on their content and metadata, and launch it globally!
110.title: Build a Smart Photo Library in an hour

111.description: In this talk Raul explores what code quality actually means and how to improve it, from CI/CD, Static code analysis, Unit test, testing Android code efficiently, libraries and architectural approach.
111.title: Code Quality in Android development

112.description: Shopify's ecommerce solution already powers over 800 000 stores across the globe. Knowing how to customize themes on Shopify gives web designers and developers a desirable set of skills that they can use to grow their business. In this introductory session, Liam will cover the basic elements of Shopify’s Liquid templating language, as well as sharing practical workflow tips, tricks, and techniques that will help you modify Shopify themes.
112.title: Getting started with Liquid and Shopify Themes

113.description: Wondering where to start when migrating your Enterprise Project into Microservices? Are you starting a Greenfield Project in Microservice Architecture? Are you anxious about scaling your Enterprise in Cloud? Struggling to translate the much-hyped theory of Microservices Architecture into working Software Systems? Are you new to the world of Microservice Architecture? What are the best practices, patterns and technologies to follow when building Cloud Native Enterprise Applications? Want to see how to Code and Deploy Secure, Resilient and Fault Tolerant Cloud Native Enterprise Microservices using Service Discovery and Load Balancing? Join this Live Programming Session to Develop and Deploy Enterprise Ready Microservices.
113.title: Cloud Native Enterprise Microservices: From Theory to Action

114.description: Make sure you won't miss closing session and the final draw to get a special prize!
114.title: DevFest Galway 2019 Closing

115.description: This session starts with a very brief history of VR starting from MIT, the problems and why it has finally becoming mainstream now. It builds up the talk with what is going in in the VR/AR landscape, the pitfalls and with an introduction to what Web Virtual Reality is along with some demo and case study with a hello world of VR live coding. The talk progresses into more real world complex situations and how it is being built now. The second part of the talk introduces the audience to Augmented Reality and when its is useful and when not. What it means to build a Mixed Reality experience. The present hardware and software stack available for it. And what they need to know if they have to build an experience. The talk will also cover ARKit, ARCore and finally the WebXR api and how we can ensure a uniform codebase that works everywhere enabling a Web Mixed Reality that can run in any device and browser with native capability. The talk ends with open research problems for Future work and how they can use this today and contribute in future. In each of first two parts we have live coding demos to actually show how to build the experiences.
115.title: State of WebXR: What do you need to know today for building Web Mixed Reality Applications

116.description: You can do so much nowadays with Web Technologies including Mobile Development. Let me show you the path that I took while developing mobile apps with React Native from a Web Developer perspective.
116.title: Switching from Web to Mobile development with React Native ⚡️

117.description: How CitySwift are applying and integrating cutting edge technology with legacy systems in a traditional industry to ensure your buses arrive on time!
117.title: Big 'Bus' Data - Integrations, Optimisations and Visualisations

118.description: I think it's about time we all had a look at Flutter: a Google framework for building iOS and Android apps natively. We'll kick this off with a quick introduction to Flutter and why you should build your next app with it. For the majority of our time, we'll be following a codelab to build our first Flutter app and get an understanding of how it works. Make sure to have an USB cable for your phone to run the app we're going to build.
118.title: Flutter Study Jam

119.description: Every developer dreams with an environment to call their own. A complete, production-like place they can tear apart testing their code without messing with other people's work, the problem with all that is this infrastructure is to complex to be created and torn down manually. That's when Kubernetes and Helm shine bright to create completely individual dynamic testing environments for each one of your branches!
119.title: Creating Dynamic Testing Environments With Helm And Kubernetes

120.description: We've all been there. Sitting, staring at the screen. Unable to process the code we wrote yesterday. But it doesn't take alcohol to get into that state. It could be a lack of caffeine, a long meeting, or the fact that somehow it's still only Tuesday. How can we write code that's easy to digest and debug even when our brain is not at 100%?
120.title: Optimise your Codebase for Hungover Developers

121.description: During the session we will build a small prototype using Cloud Run to fulfill a requirement. In the session, we will cover some of the use cases for Cloud Run and how to integrate it with other applications to minimise the code required.
121.title: An introduction to Cloud Run on Google Cloud Platform

fellyph_cintra.bio: Front-end engineer addicted learner, team worker and passionate about funny socks. I have been working professionally with front-end since 2006. Digital agencies, news portal, startups and now Consultants, I've worked with different types of companies and I brought different experience from them. My strongest is client-side front-end development. Moreover, My main domains are HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SASS, Compass, Angular and React. On server-side, I usually code in Java and PHP. Originally from Brazil, currently, I'm based in Ireland living a new challenge, working with .NET e Umbraco a new platform different than what I was working before. But my belief is: if you understand the bases and the process behind each technology, you will be able to jump between different platforms. In 2010 He attended his first WordCamp as a volunteer, 4 years later became WordCamp organizer. Since attended his first WordCamp, he already participated as a speaker in 10 more WordCamps in South America and Europe, Always talking about his favourite subject: front-end and Google technologies. Work with communities is one of my passions, in 2014 I had the chance to work as a community manager on Blackberry mobile dev group. Blackberry was my first experience with a multinational company and there I had the chance to guide 10 students and work directly with the developer community in Sao Paulo.
fellyph_cintra.name: Fellyph Cintra
fellyph_cintra.shortBio: Front-end engineer addicted learner, team worker and passionate about funny socks...
fellyph_cintra.title: Senior Solution Engineer and GDE

badges.description: Android, Internet of Things Google Developer Expert
badges.name: gde

raul_portales.bio: Raul is a Software Engineer with a strong focus on product and quality. No longer a contractor, he also co-founded a game studio called The Pill Tree, which ran for a year. He switched from Symbian to Android in early 2009 (before Android versions had tasty names) and never looked back. He loves public speaking, and has presented at several DroidCons and Game Developer Conferences. After working a lot on front end – especially building games – Raul has developed a special interest in UX and UI. His current favourite topic is Playful Design. He also maintains the Leonids library, which is a particle system for standard Android UI. While living in Amsterdam, Raul was actively involved in Appsterdam and the DutchAUG. Since moving back to Dublin, he now collaborates with the Dublin GDG.
raul_portales.name: Raul Portales
raul_portales.shortBio: Software Engineer with a strong focus on product and quality....
raul_portales.title: Senior Software Development Engineer and GDE

maurizio_parton.bio: I work at the Italian University of Chieti - Pescara since 2002. My main field of research is Differential Geometry. Since January 2016, when original AlphaGo paper on Nature has been published, I started working also in Deep Reinforcement Learning, because of my involvement in Go as a player and as president of Italian Go Association. I'm part of a research group working on a version of AlphaGo able to maximize score instead of winning rate. I love giving introductory and specialized talks on everything related to Neural Networks, Reinforcement Learning and games!
maurizio_parton.company: University of Chieti - Pescara and Italian Go Association
maurizio_parton.name: Maurizio Parton
maurizio_parton.shortBio: Professor at University of Chieti - Pescara and President of Italian Go Association
maurizio_parton.title: Associate professor at University of Chieti-Pescara, Italy; Deep Learning Italia instructor; president of Italian Go Association

emily_oneill.bio: Content Strategist at IBM Watson Health. Background in product development and testing. Passionate about digital transformations and the role of the content experience. Avid clothes maker and enthusiastic about the possibilities wearable technologies bring us. A learning addict with Masters degrees in Technical Communication and in the Management of Innovation and Technology.
emily_oneill.name: Emily O'Neill
emily_oneill.title: Content Strategist at IBM Watson Health

julien_garrigues.bio: Julien is the Head of Technology of Black Pug Studio. He is a visionary technologist fascinated by the applications of ML and AI, and code optimization. His expertise in Web Technologies and Software Programming contributed to the realisation of large projects for global brands and growing start-ups. He is also one of the Co-Organizers of GDG Galway.
julien_garrigues.name: Julien Garrigues
julien_garrigues.title: Head of Technology of Black Pug Studio and GDG Galway Co-Organizer

liam_griffin.bio: Liam Griffin lives in Sligo, Ireland, where he works as a developer advocate for Shopify, crafting technical tutorials on the Shopify Web Design and Development Blog. With experience in web-development, technical writing, and public speaking, he is passionate about developing learner resources and building better tools for developers.
liam_griffin.name: Liam Griffin
liam_griffin.title: Web developer at Shopify

sachin_sadasivan.bio: Sachin has more than a decade’s experience in Computer Programming. He is passionate about Functional, Object Oriented and Reactive Programming. He works on Enterprise Product Development in Cloud Native Microservices Architecture with Docker and Kubernetes. He also works on developing Products with Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning and Algorithms.
sachin_sadasivan.name: Sachin Sadasivan
sachin_sadasivan.title: Technical Product Owner and Senior Software Engineer at Ericsson

rabimba_karanjai.bio: Rabimba Karanjai is a full time graduate researcher, part time hacker and FOSS enthusiast. He is working with Mozilla Research Mixed Reality team on WebVR. He also is a Mozilla TechSpeaker and Google Developer Expert on Web Technologies (WebXR). And would love to chat with you on VR,AR,Security and openweb over a cup of coffee or bottle of beer.
rabimba_karanjai.name: Rabimba Karanjai
rabimba_karanjai.title: Graduate researcher, part time hacker, FOSS enthusiast and GDE

juarez_filho.bio: Writing code over the last decade for people amusement and to be readable/executable by machines. Born in Brazil. Living in Dublin with my lovely wife and the baby boy. Passionate about Web Technologies. Jesus freak.
juarez_filho.name: Juarez Filho
juarez_filho.title: Senior Developer at ERS and Google Developer Expert

brian_orourke.bio: CEO - Brian is a tech-savvy entrepreneur and former CitiBank analyst, with a range of expertise in leading big data and complex optimization projects, specifically in the mobility sector.
brian_orourke.name: Brian O'Rourke
brian_orourke.title: CEO at CitySwift

michael_mullarkey.bio: Head of Product - Computer Science Graduate, that has rapidly grown to now leading Product for CitySwift. Michael and his team have designed, developed and refined the complex product offering into a successful and scalable solution.
michael_mullarkey.name: Michael Mullarkey
michael_mullarkey.title: Head of Product at CitySwift

brian_lawless.bio: I have been working in the telecoms industry for 29 years. My career changed direction in 2017, when I went into UX Design. Since then I have learnt 'If the User cannot use your software application, it does NOT work.'
brian_lawless.name: Brian Lawless
brian_lawless.shortBio: Working with Ericsson since 1990. Being working in User Experience since 2017.
brian_lawless.title: UX Engineer at Ericsson

tommy_kearns.bio: Tommy is a final year student of BEng (Hons) Software & Electronic Engineering in GMIT. From repairing friends' handheld consoles as a child, his studies have led his curiosity and passion towards embedded systems and all things programming. Having discovered GDG Athlone (and then Galway) earlier this year, he is keen to learn more about Flutter and other Google developer technologies - while helping people out along the way.
tommy_kearns.name: Tommy Kearns

lucas_santos.bio: Lucas works as Senior Software Architect at Nindoo. Technology lover and, since 2011, works with highly available and scalable applications. Loves to teach and learn, writer of 'Kubernetes: Everything you need to know about container orchestration'. Also a Microsoft MVP and Google Developer Expert. Member & Contributor to the Node.js Foundation, helping to translate the Node.js runtime documentations to Portuguese. Also is one of the core members of several awesome communities such as: NodeBR, JSSP, VueJs SP, Typescript BR, NodeSchool SP, TrainingCenter and ABCDev. Homebrewer in the free time, loves music and games!
lucas_santos.name: Lucas Santos
lucas_santos.title: Senior Software Architect at Nindoo and GDE

richard_rose.bio: Rich Rose works in the Google Cloud Learning and Enablement team in London. Rich is responsible for creating training environments for new product areas relating to the cloud. Rich has recently written a book called Hands On Serverless with Google Cloud Platform that will be published in 2020.
richard_rose.name: Richard Rose
richard_rose.title: Google Cloud Lab Architect - Professional Cloud Architect, Professional Data Engineer at Google
